channel.title: Comments on: How To Effortlessly Generate More Power On Your Groundstrokes
channel.description: Your secret weapon on the court.

item.title: By: Teresa Davidson
item.dc:creator: Teresa Davidson
item.description: I’m interested in trying your suggestions! I didn’t see any links to video as you suggest watching…maybe bc I am on mobile?
item.content:encoded: I’m interested in trying your suggestions! I didn’t see any links to video as you suggest watching…maybe bc I am on mobile?

item.title: By: Chad Walner
item.dc:creator: Chad Walner
item.description:
In reply to <a href="/how-to-effortlessly-generate-more-power-on-your-groundstrokes/#comment-1">Brian F Murtha</a>.
You are correct, Brian. I do agree with you that the core drives the rest of the body, including the feet. But it's helpful for people to know which position to start the feet from. And it's also helpful to know where they finish. Thanks for leaving a comment and stopping by my blog.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Brian F Murtha.

You are correct, Brian. I do agree with you that the core drives the rest of the body, including the feet. But it’s helpful for people to know which position to start the feet from. And it’s also helpful to know where they finish. Thanks for leaving a comment and stopping by my blog.

item.title: By: Brian F Murtha
item.dc:creator: Brian F Murtha
item.description: Good article. The legs do not turn the body. They support the body in rotation. All human movement starts in the core and synergistic muscles in the pelvic region. Proximal to distal. It why they can turn so well often with both feet off the ground
item.content:encoded: Good article. The legs do not turn the body. They support the body in rotation. All human movement starts in the core and synergistic muscles in the pelvic region. Proximal to distal. It why they can turn so well often with both feet off the ground
